phase_gaps.description: Move-in has ZERO dedicated UI elements from either run. ds-ui-1831-006 (Acceptance Celebration) bridges toward it but does not design the move-in experience itself. The L0 comparison marks combined coverage as 'absent'. The L6 guest coherence report explicitly notes: 'move-in is where the physical world interrupts the digital flow channel' but no element addresses how to extend the platform's structure into the physical move-in. Feels-006 in Run B covers both acceptance and move-in in a single element, which the L6 report itself flags as insufficient: 'move-in deserves its own dedicated emotional element.'
phase_gaps.recommended_fix: Dedicated future run with a lens focused on physical-to-digital transition (e.g., Norman's 'knowledge in the world' chapter or Csikszentmihalyi's everyday flow chapter). Must produce: (1) a guest-side Move-In Checklist Card with host contact, arrival protocol, and neighborhood orientation; (2) a host-side Move-In Preparation Card with guest arrival details, key exchange protocol, and first-stay expectations. This is the single biggest gap in the entire library (25 of 420 elements).

phase_gaps.description: L0 marks combined evaluation coverage as 'thin'. Run A's host evaluation phase (comparing Split Lease to Craigslist/Airbnb/word-of-mouth) has no dedicated UI element. Run A's L6 coherence report explicitly flags this: 'No element addresses the specific moment where the host compares Split Lease to alternatives.' The Freud insight that 'we should be much happier if we were to give it up and go back to primitive conditions' maps directly to this comparison moment, but no element operationalizes it.
phase_gaps.recommended_fix: A host evaluation element that addresses the cost-of-civilization calculation: 'What does Split Lease give me that finding someone on my own does not?' This could be a comparison card showing platform protections (vetting, payment security, dispute resolution) against DIY risks. A behavioral economics lens (Thaler/Ariely) would ground this effectively.

phase_gaps.description: L0 marks combined acceptance coverage as 'thin'. Run B provides ds-ui-1831-006 (Acceptance Celebration and Orientation Bridge) for the guest side, but NO host-side acceptance element exists from either run. When a guest accepts a proposal, the host has no designed experience for seeing that commitment confirmed. The L0 notes: 'The host's experience of a proposal being accepted (seeing that a guest has committed) is uncovered.'
phase_gaps.recommended_fix: Design a Host Acceptance Confirmation Card that mirrors the guest celebration: shows the confirmed guest's trust signals, confirmed terms, and a 'What happens next' timeline for the host (lease document preparation, move-in day logistics, first stay cycle expectations). The Freud lens would frame this as the moment the civilizational contract becomes real -- the stranger is now an official guest.

phase_gaps.description: L0 marks combined pricing coverage as 'thin'. Pricing is addressed only as one step of ds-ui-1830-002 (Listing Wizard Progress Card). No element designs the pricing interface itself -- the smart defaults, the market comparison, the fee transparency. Run A's L6 coherence report identifies pricing as loaded with instinctual anxiety ('sublimation of emotional attachment into economic value') and explicitly recommends a future run with a behavioral economics lens for this phase. The L6 also notes: 'The pricing phase has no dedicated emotional element.'
phase_gaps.recommended_fix: A pricing-specific run with Thaler/Ariely behavioral economics lens to address the endowment effect (hosts overvalue their space), anchoring (market comps as reference points), and fee transparency. Must produce a Smart Pricing Card with market comparison data, fee breakdown with bidirectional framing ('hosts in your area earn X after fees'), and a confidence-building preview ('This is what guests will see').

phase_gaps.description: The guest-side listing detail page has no dedicated UI element from either run. ds-ui-1831-003 (Conversational Message Composer) serves as a bridge from evaluation to proposal, but no element designs the listing page layout itself -- the photo gallery, amenity display, neighborhood context, host profile section, or trust signal placement on the full listing detail view. L0 notes: 'no element addresses the listing page itself -- the layout, information hierarchy, or trust signal placement on the guest-facing listing detail page.'
phase_gaps.recommended_fix: A Listing Detail Page Layout element that specifies: photo gallery with image counter, amenity grid, neighborhood context (extending the Living Map to listing-level), host profile with trust signals, availability calendar, and the Message Host CTA positioned as intermediate action before proposal. The Flow lens's challenge-skill escalation applies: the listing page is the A2-to-A3 bridge where the guest builds enough confidence to message.

phase_gaps.description: Run B provides ds-ui-1831-005 (Collaborative Negotiation Comparison Card) for the guest side. Run A covers the host counter-proposal at the principle level within proposal_mgmt but produces no dedicated HOST-side negotiation UI element. L0 notes: 'Run A covers the host counter-proposal as part of proposal_mgmt but does not produce a dedicated host-side negotiation UI element. The host's counter-offer creation interface is uncovered.'
phase_gaps.recommended_fix: Design a Host Counter-Proposal Builder that implements the Freudian empowered gatekeeping emotion: the host adjusts terms using a slider/field interface with pre-calculated guest-impact preview. The interface should frame counter-proposing as 'adjusting terms' (authority) not 'bargaining' (concession). Market calibration data should appear for the host too, preventing information asymmetry.

phase_gaps.description: Run A provides ds-ui-1830-007 (Hosting Summary and Retention Continuation Card) for host retention. Guest retention -- lease renewal, re-booking with same or different host -- is not addressed by either run. The L0 notes: 'Guest retention (lease renewal, re-booking with same or different host) is not addressed by either run.'
phase_gaps.recommended_fix: Design a Guest Re-Booking Card that appears near lease end, showing cumulative stay history, review record, and a one-tap renewal or 'explore new listings' path. The Flow lens would frame this as the reflection-to-new-cycle transition that prevents post-lease boredom. The host retention card (ds-ui-1830-007) provides a structural template.

phase_gaps.description: Run B covers discovery at the principle level (works-006, communicates-005, feels-001) but produces no dedicated guest discovery UI element. The L0 notes: 'The guest discovery landing experience has no buildable component from either run.' Run A has ds-ui-1830-001 (Discovery Earnings Estimator) for hosts, but no guest equivalent exists.
phase_gaps.recommended_fix: A Guest Discovery Landing Card that shows real listings, neighborhood highlights, and platform trust signals before any sign-up. Must implement the 'distinct world' quality that Csikszentmihalyi requires for flow entry -- the landing must feel visually different from everyday browsing. Current principles are strong but there is no buildable component.

element_quality_issues.description: The Living Map HTML is a static mockup using CSS gradients and positioned divs to simulate a map interface. In production this would require a real map library (Mapbox, Leaflet, Google Maps) with custom pin components. The HTML/CSS as written cannot be rendered as a functional map -- it is a visual wireframe only. The proximity-scaling pin behavior (8px rest, 12px near, 16px hover) and neighborhood boundary dwell-reveal require JavaScript event handlers that are not included. The transit labels and price pills are hardcoded positions that would need dynamic calculation from geocoded data.

The Living Map specifies pin proximity scaling ('8px at rest, 12px within 60px radius, 16px at cursor nearest') but does not define the mathematical proximity function, the performance budget for mousemove event throttling, or the behavior on touch devices where hover-based proximity is unavailable. Mobile is described as 'full-screen toggle' but the interaction model for touch-based neighborhood discovery is unspecified.

The Progressive Density Listing Card uses an Unsplash placeholder image URL (https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1522708323590-d24dbb6b0267) that would not be valid in production. Minor issue, but all HTML snippets intended for production rendering should use relative paths or placeholder conventions. The card's expanded drawer uses position:absolute bottom:0 with translateY, which may cause layout issues in a CSS Grid search results context where card heights are not fixed.

The save-heart icon uses color var(--favorites-heart, #FF6B5B) -- a coral/red color that does not exist in the production style guide or tokens.json. Run B's own L6 coherence report flags this: 'No coral color exists in tokens.json or Style-guide.md. If a save/favorite interaction needs a distinct color, it should use an existing palette color.' This token has not been resolved.

The Bidirectional Protection Confirmation Dialog is well-specified visually but may be over-reliant on Freudian framing without concrete grounding in user call evidence. The copy spec ('Both parties are protected', bidirectional constraint statements) assumes the host experiences platform rules as one-sided restrictions, but no specific call transcript excerpt is cited. The dialog pattern is sound UX, but the Freudian justification ('first requisite of culture is justice') may be more theoretical decoration than evidence-grounded insight.

The Stay Cycle Ritual Card's cleaning photo grid uses placeholder gradient backgrounds instead of actual image placeholders. More critically, the spec describes 'Photo thumbnails populate progressively as each photo uploads' but no upload interaction is specified -- how does the guest submit cleaning photos? Is there a camera/upload affordance? The card is host-facing (viewing submitted photos) but the companion guest-side submission interface is not designed.

The Collaborative Negotiation Comparison Card uses hardcoded example values ($850/night, 16 vs 10 weeks) that show a host SHORTENING a duration (from guest's 16 weeks to 10). The spec does not address the inverse case (host extending or changing schedule), rate changes, or multi-dimension changes (rate AND duration). The 'Suggest a modification' button is described as expanding to 'guided fields' but those fields are not specified in the visual or interaction spec.

The Evolving Stays Manager describes three lifecycle phases (orientation weeks 1-3, rhythm weeks 4-9, reflection weeks 10-13) but only shows the rhythm phase state (Week 6 of 13) in the HTML. The orientation and reflection phase states are described in copy_spec but have no HTML/CSS implementation. A production team would need to design three distinct content states, not one.

The Hosting Summary and Retention Continuation Card's timeline visualization uses three hardcoded div segments with different opacity values (.5, .7, 1.0). This is structurally correct for a 3-lease host but does not scale to arbitrary lease counts. The timeline would need a dynamic rendering approach for hosts with 1, 5, or 10 leases. The visual spec says 'varying opacity per lease' but does not define the opacity calculation function.

The Pre-Populated Proposal Builder shows '$850/night x 13 weeks = $11,050' as the total calculation. However, $850/night x 4 nights/week x 13 weeks = $44,200, not $11,050. The pricing model appears confused between nightly rates and weekly rates. This arithmetic error undermines the element's credibility as a production-ready spec. The listing card also shows '$850/night' which at $850 per night for a 4-night-per-week schedule would be a very different total than what is displayed.

cross_run_contradictions.topic: Stays Manager temporal strategy: ritual repetition vs. complexity ratchet
cross_run_contradictions.run_a_position: ds-ui-1830-006 (Stay Cycle Ritual Card) uses identical layout for every stay cycle. Freud: 'order is a kind of repetition-compulsion by which doubt and hesitation shall be avoided.' The host needs the same card, same structure, same three beats every single week to contain anxiety about the stranger in their space.
cross_run_contradictions.run_b_position: ds-ui-1831-007 (Evolving Stays Manager) must evolve across three lifecycle phases. Csikszentmihalyi: 'One cannot enjoy doing the same thing at the same level for long.' Content within the stable skeleton must change weekly to prevent mid-lease boredom.
cross_run_contradictions.resolution: Not a true contradiction -- these address different sides of the marketplace. The HOST Stays Manager should be ritualistically consistent (Freud's order principle): same layout, same three beats, same card structure every week. The GUEST Stays Manager should evolve within a stable skeleton (Flow's complexity ratchet): stable three-zone architecture, but content within each zone evolves across orientation/rhythm/reflection phases. Both share the three-zone architecture; they differ in how content within the skeleton behaves. The L0 comparison correctly identifies this as a 'scope_difference' not a real tension.

cross_run_contradictions.topic: Review frequency: per-stay micro-reviews vs. batched narrative reviews
cross_run_contradictions.run_a_position: ds-ui-1830-006 includes a micro-review prompt as the third beat of every stay ritual. The host needs regular evidence that the guest is respecting the arrangement. Freud's repetition-compulsion justifies this: the review is part of the civilizational order.
cross_run_contradictions.run_b_position: Run B's behaves-004 proposes one-tap micro-reviews during the rhythm phase (weeks 4-9). But this contradicts the existing library element (Batched Review Prompts at Natural Reflection Points) which explicitly warns: 'DO NOT prompt for a review after every single stay.' The L6 guest coherence report flags this as the highest-priority contradiction.
cross_run_contradictions.resolution: Adopt a hybrid that both L6 reports independently recommend: (1) 3-point NARRATIVE reviews (text-based, at weeks 4, midpoint, and final) remain the primary review mechanism for both host and guest -- this preserves the existing library's validated approach. (2) Add optional ONE-TAP MICRO-RATINGS (single 5-point scale, no text, no expansion unless user-initiated) for the HOST's stay ritual card as anxiety containment (Freud), not engagement escalation. (3) The guest's micro-rating in rhythm phase should be truly optional -- appearing as an invitation, never accumulating as unaddressed tasks. The key distinction: narrative reviews are for quality feedback; micro-ratings are for anxiety containment (host) and engagement maintenance (guest). Different purposes, different mechanisms.

cross_run_contradictions.topic: Negotiation framing: gatekeeping vs. collaborative game
cross_run_contradictions.run_a_position: The host experiences negotiation as 'vigilant gatekeeping' (feels-004). Counter-proposing is a controlled assertion of remaining autonomy: 'I accept this stranger, but on my terms.' Emphasis on host's power to modify terms.
cross_run_contradictions.run_b_position: The guest should experience negotiation as collaborative agon -- 'seeking together' (feels-005). ds-ui-1831-005 (Collaborative Negotiation Comparison Card) provides market calibration data and a 'Suggest a change' option that transforms binary accept/reject into a skilled game.
cross_run_contradictions.resolution: Both framings are correct for their respective sides. The platform should present the SAME underlying data with different emotional framing: the host sees 'Adjust terms' as an exercise of authority (gatekeeping); the guest sees 'Suggest a change' as a collaborative move (agon). Market calibration data must be available to BOTH sides to prevent information asymmetry. The proposal review card (host) and negotiation comparison card (guest) are complementary components of a single marketplace negotiation system, not competing visions.

cross_run_contradictions.run_a_position: Not directly addressed (host run does not design the proposal builder).
cross_run_contradictions.run_b_position: ds-ui-1831-004 shows '$850/night x 13 weeks = $11,050' which is arithmetically inconsistent. At $850/night for a Thu-Sun schedule (4 nights), 13 weeks = $44,200. At $850/week, 13 weeks = $11,050. The nightly vs. weekly rate confusion creates an internal contradiction within Run B's own element.
cross_run_contradictions.resolution: The pricing model must be clarified platform-wide before this element can be implemented. If the rate is per-night ($850/night x 4 nights/week x 13 weeks = $44,200), the total in the spec is wrong. If the rate is per-week ($850/week x 13 weeks = $11,050), the '/night' label is wrong. The L0 comparison does not catch this because it evaluates thematic coherence, not arithmetic. Resolution: establish whether Split Lease uses nightly or weekly pricing, then correct all UI elements' copy specs accordingly.

blind_spots.blind_spot: Inline authentication modal -- the actual UI component
blind_spots.evidence: User stories explicitly state: 'Authentication should be invisible until it matters. Inline auth pop-up, not a full-page redirect. Users don't lose search context.' Both runs identify this as structurally critical (Run A: Freudian premature demand; Run B: Flow concentration disruption). Both L0 and L6 reports reference it extensively. Yet NEITHER run produces a dedicated UI element for the inline auth modal itself. The principle is embedded in multiple elements but no run designs the actual auth component. L0 'partially_addressed' section confirms: 'no run designs the actual auth component.'
blind_spots.suggested_lens: Norman (affordances/signifiers) or Krug (Don't Make Me Think) -- the auth modal is a pure interaction design problem that benefits from a usability lens more than a psychological one.

blind_spots.evidence: User stories state: 'Verified reviews and host credibility signals activate guests. The trust infrastructure is cross-activation infrastructure.' Run A's ds-ui-1830-004 places trust signals above proposal terms. Run B's communicates-003 distributes trust signals across phases. But the L0 confirms: 'no UI element specifically designs the review display component or the trust badge component itself -- trust is addressed architecturally but not as a standalone buildable element.' There is no standalone Trust Badge Component or Review Display Card in either run.
blind_spots.suggested_lens: Cialdini (social proof / authority) -- the review display is a social proof mechanism that benefits from a persuasion lens.

blind_spots.blind_spot: Experienced guest's history surfaced to new hosts
blind_spots.evidence: User stories state: 'An experienced guest applying to a new host is cross-activation in action. That guest's reputation does the selling.' L0 marks this as 'not_addressed': 'neither run produces a UI element that specifically surfaces an experienced guest's history to a new host.' ds-ui-1830-004 (Proposal Review Card) shows lease history and rating, which implicitly covers this, but it is not designed as a first-host-specific experience where the platform actively surfaces the guest's track record as a trust accelerator.
blind_spots.suggested_lens: Cialdini (social proof) or Cold Start Problem (network effects) -- this is about leveraging existing network participants to activate new ones.

blind_spots.blind_spot: Map on listing detail page (neighborhood context beyond search)
blind_spots.evidence: User stories demand the map should 'feel alive' with 'transit stops, landmarks, real-time context.' ds-ui-1831-002 (Living Map) addresses this for search, but L0 notes the gap: 'it is a search-phase component only. The user stories imply the map should also serve listing evaluation (neighborhood context on the listing page), which is not addressed.' The listing detail page has no map/neighborhood context component.
blind_spots.suggested_lens: Norman (knowledge in the world) -- the listing page map is about providing environmental context that reduces the guest's need to hold location information in their head.

blind_spots.evidence: ds-ui-1830-006 (Stay Cycle Ritual Card) shows the host viewing cleaning photos as part of the three-beat ritual. But the companion guest-side interface for submitting these photos is never designed. The ritual card depends on the guest submitting photos, but neither run designs the submission experience. This is a structural dependency gap -- the host-facing card cannot function without the guest-facing submission flow.
blind_spots.suggested_lens: Norman (feedback/mapping) -- the photo submission is a physical-to-digital bridge that benefits from an affordance/signifier lens.

blind_spots.evidence: ds-ui-1830-002 (Listing Wizard Progress Card) addresses the dashboard-level view of listing creation progress. L0 notes: 'the 6-step wizard itself (the screens within each step) has no dedicated UI element from either run. The wizard progress card is the external view; the internal wizard experience is uncovered.' Step labels are listed (Space details, Features & amenities, Lease style, Pricing, House rules, Photos) but no step's actual screen is designed.
blind_spots.suggested_lens: Krug (Don't Make Me Think) or 100 Things Every Designer Needs to Know -- the wizard steps are pure form design problems.

blind_spots.evidence: Run B's L6 coherence report identifies a novel extension (behaves-006): 'No existing element treats error states as flow redirection opportunities.' This is flagged as an extension but no UI element implements it. Neither run produces an error state component (failed submission, network error, unavailable listing, auth failure). Error recovery is a blind spot across both runs.
blind_spots.suggested_lens: Norman (error handling / constraints) -- error recovery is a core interaction design problem.

user_story_fulfillment.story: Listing cards want more layers (richer hover states, image counters, availability indicators, neighborhood labels, quick actions)
user_story_fulfillment.gap: None. ds-ui-1831-001 (Progressive Density Listing Card) addresses every specific request: three-tier hover with neighborhood name (Tier 2), image counter badge (Tier 2), availability dot (Tier 1), and Message Host quick-action (Tier 3 drawer). HTML/CSS is production-quality with complete interaction specs.

user_story_fulfillment.story: Messaging before proposals is a natural step (park analogy -- check availability before committing)
user_story_fulfillment.gap: None. ds-ui-1831-003 (Conversational Message Composer) fully addresses this with host profile, suggested questions, response time indicator, and post-send guidance. Both L0 convergent themes and L6 reports validate messaging as the highest cross-activation story.

user_story_fulfillment.story: Authentication should be invisible until it matters (inline auth pop-up, not full-page redirect)
user_story_fulfillment.gap: CRITICAL GAP. Both runs identify this as structurally essential (Freud: premature demand triggers revolt; Flow: context switch destroys concentration). Both L6 reports reference it. But NEITHER run produces a UI element for the actual inline auth modal. The principle is embedded in multiple elements' interaction specs (e.g., ds-ui-1831-001's drawer triggers auth only on Message Host) but no standalone component exists. This is the most significant blind spot relative to user story explicitness.

user_story_fulfillment.story: The map should feel alive (transit stops, landmarks, real-time context)
user_story_fulfillment.gap: ds-ui-1831-002 (Living Map) addresses the alive-map story for search with pin proximity scaling, neighborhood boundaries, and transit labels. However: (1) it is search-phase only -- no map component exists for listing detail pages; (2) the HTML is a static mockup, not a real map integration; (3) mobile interaction model is unspecified; (4) 'landmarks' from the user story are not addressed (only transit and neighborhoods).

user_story_fulfillment.story: Completion percentage is a good host nudge (visible progress indicator on listing card)
user_story_fulfillment.gap: None. ds-ui-1830-002 (Listing Wizard Progress Card) shows completion bar (67%), step-by-step status with check/pending/current indicators, and amber badges for steps needing attention. Copy spec positively frames progress ('4 of 6 steps complete') and encouragement ('Your space is looking great').

user_story_fulfillment.story: Pause matters more than delete (preserve work, keep the door open)
user_story_fulfillment.gap: None. ds-ui-1830-002 has a frictionless 'Pause this listing' text link while delete is buried. ds-ui-1830-007 offers one-action continuation at retention. Freud's reversibility principle provides the theoretical grounding. The L6 host coherence report marks this as a strong extension of existing save-and-resume patterns.

user_story_fulfillment.story: Urgency should surface first on the dashboard (unread proposals, pending actions, incomplete listings)
user_story_fulfillment.gap: None. ds-ui-1830-003 (Host Dashboard Urgency-First Action Panel) places action items at the fixed-position top with amber indicators. ds-ui-1831-007 (Evolving Stays Manager) uses a collapsible action band at top. Both independently derive the three-zone architecture with urgency at top. L0 confirms this convergence as a platform-wide design standard.

user_story_fulfillment.story: Value before the ask -- always (show something useful first, offer to refine after)
user_story_fulfillment.gap: None. ds-ui-1830-001 (Discovery Earnings Estimator) shows earnings data before any sign-up for hosts. ds-ui-1831-001 (Progressive Density Listing Card) delivers rich search results without authentication for guests. Both L0 convergent themes confirm this as the strongest cross-run convergence: two independent theoretical frameworks (Freud's instinctual economics + Csikszentmihalyi's flow prerequisites) arrive at the same prescription.

user_story_fulfillment.story: Proposal form should pre-populate with listing details (cross-activation: structured proposals activate hosts)
user_story_fulfillment.gap: Minor: ds-ui-1831-004 (Pre-Populated Proposal Builder) has the pricing arithmetic error described in element_quality_issues. ds-ui-1830-004 (Proposal Review Card) addresses the host's view of the structured proposal. Together they form a matched pair. But the pricing confusion ($850/night vs. per-week) needs resolution before implementation.

user_story_fulfillment.story: Messaging is the highest cross-activation story (when a guest messages a host, two strangers begin to trust each other through the platform)
user_story_fulfillment.gap: None. ds-ui-1831-003 (Conversational Message Composer) directly implements this. Host profile visible alongside compose area, suggested questions reduce self-consciousness, response time indicator sets expectations. L0 identifies this as the strongest cross-activation convergence: Run A frames it as civilizational compliance evidence; Run B frames it as flow-enabling intermediate challenge.

user_story_fulfillment.story: Verified reviews and host credibility signals activate guests (trust infrastructure is cross-activation infrastructure)
user_story_fulfillment.gap: ds-ui-1830-004 places trust signals (verification badge, lease history, avg rating, member since) above proposal terms. But this is the HOST's view of the guest's trust signals, not the guest's view of the host's trust signals. No standalone Review Display Component or Trust Badge Component exists for the guest to see host credibility. L0 confirms: 'trust is addressed architecturally but not as a standalone buildable element.'

user_story_fulfillment.story: An experienced guest applying to a new host is cross-activation in action
user_story_fulfillment.gap: ds-ui-1830-004's trust zone shows guest's lease history and rating, which implicitly surfaces an experienced guest's track record. But it is not designed as a FIRST-HOST-SPECIFIC experience where the platform actively highlights: 'This is an experienced guest who has completed 3 leases with 4.9 average rating -- they know how Split Lease works.' The cross-activation potential is present in the data but not in the emotional framing.

user_story_fulfillment.story: The proposal itself is a cross-activation event (well-structured proposal activates the host to respond)
user_story_fulfillment.gap: None. ds-ui-1831-004 (Pre-Populated Proposal Builder) ensures proposals arrive well-structured from the guest side. ds-ui-1830-004 (Proposal Review Card with Trust-First Architecture) ensures the host receives them in a trust-optimized format. The L0 convergent theme on structured proposals confirms: 'Run A reveals WHY the host needs structured proposals (stranger-threat resolution). Run B reveals WHY the guest needs pre-populated proposals (self-consciousness reduction). Together they form a complete design specification.'

priority_recommendations.recommendation: Fix the pricing arithmetic in ds-ui-1831-004 and establish a platform-wide pricing model
priority_recommendations.rationale: The Pre-Populated Proposal Builder contains a critical arithmetic error ($850/night x 13 weeks showing $11,050 total, which is internally inconsistent). This element is at the single highest-stakes cross-activation moment in the platform. If the pricing model is wrong in the spec, it will be wrong in production. Additionally, the broader pricing phase has only 'thin' coverage across both runs.
priority_recommendations.suggested_approach: Clarify whether Split Lease uses nightly or weekly pricing. Update ds-ui-1831-004's copy spec to be arithmetically correct. Then consider a dedicated pricing run with a behavioral economics lens (Thaler/Ariely) to address the endowment effect, anchoring, and fee transparency -- producing both the host-side pricing interface and the guest-side price display.

priority_recommendations.recommendation: Design the inline authentication modal as a standalone UI element
priority_recommendations.rationale: This is explicitly called out in the user stories, identified as critical by both runs' theoretical frameworks, referenced in both L6 coherence reports, and yet has zero buildable UI elements across either run. It is the single most explicitly requested user story that has no covering element. Every high-intent action (messaging, proposing) depends on it.
priority_recommendations.suggested_approach: Design a context-preserving inline auth modal that: (1) overlays the current view without destroying scroll/filter state; (2) supports multiple auth methods (email, social, phone); (3) uses the production purple palette; (4) auto-dismisses on success with a brief confirmation; (5) preserves the user's intended action and resumes it after auth. This can be designed without a specific psychological lens -- it is a pure interaction design problem.

priority_recommendations.recommendation: Design move-in phase UI elements for both host and guest
priority_recommendations.rationale: Move-in is marked 'absent' in the L0 phase coverage matrix, has only 25 of 420 library elements, and both L6 reports flag it as the most significant remaining gap. Both runs' theoretical lenses identify it as critical (Freud: the moment the stranger physically enters the space; Flow: where the physical world interrupts the digital flow channel) but neither produces a buildable component.
priority_recommendations.suggested_approach: A dedicated cross-run (host + guest) with Norman's 'knowledge in the world' chapter or a physical-to-digital transition lens. Must produce: (1) Guest Move-In Checklist Card (arrival protocol, key exchange, first-night orientation); (2) Host Move-In Preparation Card (guest arrival details, space preparation checklist, first-stay expectations); (3) House Manual component that serves as Flow's 'culture' -- defensive construction against move-in chaos.

priority_recommendations.recommendation: Resolve the review frequency contradiction with the hybrid model both L6 reports recommend
priority_recommendations.rationale: This is the highest-severity contradiction identified by both coherence reports independently. ds-ui-1830-006 includes per-stay review beats; the existing library explicitly prohibits per-stay review prompts. The unresolved tension will create implementation confusion if both elements are merged into the library without a canonical resolution.
priority_recommendations.suggested_approach: Formalize the hybrid: (1) 3-point narrative reviews at weeks 4, midpoint, and final (existing library pattern, canonical); (2) Optional one-tap micro-ratings (5-point scale, no text, no expansion unless initiated) for the HOST's stay ritual card during rhythm phase; (3) Optional one-tap micro-ratings for the GUEST during rhythm phase, never appearing as unaddressed tasks. Document this as a platform-wide Review Strategy element that supersedes both the existing batched review element and the new micro-review prescriptions.

priority_recommendations.recommendation: Design host-side acceptance and counter-proposal creation UI elements
priority_recommendations.rationale: Two significant host-side gaps: (1) No host acceptance confirmation experience exists -- when a guest commits, the host has no designed celebration/orientation moment. (2) No host counter-proposal creation interface exists -- Run A covers counter-proposals at the principle level but produces no dedicated UI. The guest side has both (ds-ui-1831-005 for negotiation, ds-ui-1831-006 for acceptance) but the host side is missing the mirror components.
priority_recommendations.suggested_approach: Design: (1) Host Acceptance Confirmation Card showing confirmed guest trust signals, terms, and next-steps timeline (mirrors ds-ui-1831-006's structure); (2) Host Counter-Proposal Builder with term adjustment sliders, guest-impact preview, and market calibration data (mirrors ds-ui-1831-005's information architecture but framed as authority/gatekeeping rather than collaboration).

priority_recommendations.recommendation: Complete ds-ui-1831-007 (Evolving Stays Manager) with all three lifecycle phase states
priority_recommendations.rationale: The element describes three lifecycle phases (orientation, rhythm, reflection) but only implements the rhythm phase in HTML/CSS. This is the platform's most-visited page (13+ times per lease) and the element with the most theoretical reinforcement (five independent lenses). A production team receiving only the rhythm-phase HTML would have to guess at the orientation and reflection states.
priority_recommendations.suggested_approach: Produce full HTML/CSS for all three states: (1) Orientation (weeks 1-3): checklist-focused with House Manual access, arrival confirmation, first-message prompts; (2) Rhythm (weeks 4-9): existing implementation with timeline, micro-rating, stay info; (3) Reflection (weeks 10-13): cumulative stats, review prompts, re-booking or new search path. Each state should share the stable three-zone skeleton with different content.

priority_recommendations.recommendation: Design standalone Trust Badge and Review Display components
priority_recommendations.rationale: User stories identify 'verified reviews and host credibility signals' as cross-activation infrastructure. Trust signals are addressed architecturally across both runs (information hierarchy, placement) but no standalone component exists. The L6 guest coherence report also flags a contradiction between green trust badges (tokens.json) and purple trust badges (production), which can only be resolved by designing the canonical component.
priority_recommendations.suggested_approach: Design: (1) Trust Badge Component with verification checkmark, member-since date, and credibility tier; (2) Review Display Card with review summary (aggregate rating, review count), individual review entries, and temporal narrative (how ratings evolved). Use the production purple palette and the shield-check + pill pattern recommended by the L6 guest coherence report. This resolves both the green-vs-purple token conflict and the missing buildable component.

priority_recommendations.recommendation: Design guest-side cleaning photo submission interface
priority_recommendations.rationale: ds-ui-1830-006 (Stay Cycle Ritual Card) depends on the guest submitting cleaning photos, but the guest-side submission interface is never designed. This is a structural dependency: the host-facing ritual card cannot function without its companion guest-facing submission flow. The cleaning photo beat is the second of three ritual confirmations that Freud's order principle requires.
priority_recommendations.suggested_approach: Design a Cleaning Photo Submission Card for the guest Stays Manager that: (1) appears at departure within the rhythm-phase content; (2) uses camera/upload affordance with 2x2 photo grid; (3) provides instant confirmation that photos were received; (4) frames submission as part of the stay cycle ritual, not as surveillance. The Flow lens would position this as a micro-challenge within the rhythm phase complexity ratchet.

priority_recommendations.recommendation: Reconcile tokens.json with the production style guide
priority_recommendations.rationale: Both L6 coherence reports, the L0 comparison, and the MEMORY.md all flag the same persistent token drift: tokens.json uses warm green accent (#2d5a3d) while production uses purple (#31135D). All 14 UI elements across both runs correctly reference the production palette, but tokens.json remains stale. This drift will cause confusion for any developer using tokens.json as a reference.
priority_recommendations.suggested_approach: Update tokens.json to match the production style guide's purple palette. Deprecate the green accent. Formalize the seven new semantic tokens proposed in Run A's L6 report (--container-bg-warm, --trust-badge-bg, --font-evidence, --urgency-badge-bg/text, --zone-gap, --metric-hero-size, --protection-surface-bg). Remove the proposed --accent-coral from Run B's ds-ui-1831-001 and replace with an existing palette color.

priority_recommendations.recommendation: Design guest discovery landing experience as a buildable component
priority_recommendations.rationale: Both runs have strong principle-level coverage of discovery (value-before-investment converges across Freud and Flow), and the host side has ds-ui-1830-001 (Discovery Earnings Estimator). But the guest discovery landing has no buildable component. L0 confirms: 'Run B covers discovery at the principle level but produces no dedicated discovery UI element for guests.'
priority_recommendations.suggested_approach: Design a Guest Discovery Landing Component that shows real listings (from the Progressive Density Card), neighborhood highlights (from the Living Map), and platform trust signals before any sign-up. Must implement Flow's 'distinct world' quality -- the landing should feel visually different from everyday browsing through the production purple palette and immersive listing content.
